document.docAuthor: Namyatova, Anna A. & Konstantinov, Fedor V.
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the genus Orthocephalus Fieber, 1858 (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Miridae: Orthotylinae) 2316

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the genus Orthocephalus Fieber, 1858 (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Miridae: Orthotylinae) 2316

subSubSection.paragraph:
DIAGNOSIS: Male recognized by the yellowish antennal segment I and longitudinal stripe on the outer margin of clavus and inner part of corium (fig. 4), the dark minute rounded spots on the pale femora, relatively large body size, and the aedeagus with somewhat curved apex and base of the long spicule, short spicule commashaped, half as long as long spicule (fig. 9). Female recognized by the same femoral color pattern, hemelytra often dark brown to black or with small stripe or spot along claval suture, and dorsal labiate plate with medial sclerites curved and wide, of approximately the same length and width as the sclerotized ring (fig. 17). Dark females are similar to those of
O. funestus ,
but that species can be separated by having narrow medial sclerites (fig. 15).

REDESCRIPTION: Macropterous; length 5.5–6.7. COLORATION (fig. 4): Head : dark brown; spot near inner margin and stripe along posterior margin of eye pale brown or yellowish, maxillary plate often with pale brown or yellowish stripe below antennal fossa; antennal segment I yellowish, darkened at base, segments II, III, and IV often brown, sometimes pale brown; labial segments I and II often paler than segment III, sometimes labium uniformly dark brown. Thorax : Pronotum and pleurites dark brown; evaporatorium yellowish; scutellum dark brown; forecoxa yellowish, femur yellowish or pale brown with darker spots; tibiae yellowish, apically darkened, with spots at base of tibial spines; tarsus dark brown to black; hemelytra with dirty yellow longitudinal stripe on outer part of clavus and inner part of corium, usually occupying entire inner half of corium, rarely very thin or indistinct, sometimes hemelytra with narrow yellow stripe along outer margin of corium; membrane with darker minute rounded spots, often apically darkened. Abdomen : Uniformly dark brown to black. SURFACE AND VESTITURE: As in
O. bivittatus
(as in figs. 22 A-C, E, 23 A, D). STRUC- TURE AND MEASUREMENTS: Body 3.7–4.2× as long as width of pronotum. Head : Shape of head and eye similar to those of
O. bivittatus
(as in figs. 20 B, 21 A, G) head 1.2–1.3× as wide as high, depression along hind margin of vertex weak, sometimes indistinct; vertex 1.8–2.1× as wide as eye; eye located at a short distance from anterior pronotal margin; antennal fossa located close to inferior margin of eye; antennal segment I as long as or somewhat longer than diameter of eye, segment II thin, almost not incrassate, 0.9–1.1× as long as basal width of pronotum, 1.1–1.4× as long as width of head, labium reaching middle coxa. Thorax : Pronotum 1.9–2.3× as wide as long and 1.2- 1.5× as wide as head, with posterior margin of pronotum straight or slightly concave, lateral margin not carinate, calli slightly raised; hind femora not swollen, approximately 1.5× as wide as middle femora. GENITALIA: Aedeagus with two spicules, long spicule robust, apically tapering, longer than dorsal wall of theca, more or less curved at apex and at base, directed to mouth of theca, short spicule half as long as long one, comma-shaped, variously directed (fig. 9); parameres as in fig. 13.

DISTRIBUTION: Widely distributed in the western Palaearctic. The distributional range includes virtually all European countries and spans north to Finland and Karelia, south to Turkey and Israel, and east to Yakutia and Mongolia.
New for Kyrgyzstan and Turkmenistan .

HOSTS: This species was recorded from Asteraceae :
Achillea milefolium ( Franz and Wagner, 1961 )
and
Achillea tomentosa ( Tamanini, 1981 )
,
Chrysanthemum leucanthemum ( Franz and Wagner, 1961 )
,
Chrysanthemum sp.
( Tamanini, 1981 ); from Fabaceae :
Ononis spinosa ( Göllner-Scheiding, 1970 )
; specimens from the ZISP collection were sampled from
Spiraea sp.
( Rosaceae ) by I. M. Kerzhner and form
Rosa rugosa
( Rosaceae ) by an unknown collector.

DISCUSSION: Wagner (1942) described a new subspecies,
O. vittipennis decipiens
, on the basis of a single male collected from Kahlbude, Poland and deposited in the Hamburg Zoologisches Museum. According to Wagner, this specimen was erroneously determined as
O. saltator ,
but is similar to
O. vittipennis
in the large body size, broadened hemelytra with pale brown stripe, large eyes, and longer antennal segment II, whereas
O. saltator
is smaller, with parallel sides and uniformly dark colored hemelytra, smaller eyes and shorter antennal segment II. Wagner also provided a short description of the new subspecies, in which he mentioned the following characters: black and shining body and appendages, black hemelytra having paler stripe at the base of claval suture, brownish black membrane darkened along the edge, femora paler at apices, pale brown fore and middle tibiae darkened apically and basally. Unfortunately, the holotype of
O. vittipennis decipiens
was unavailable for the study. Typically, most specimens of
O. vittipennis
have a yellowish antennal segment

I, yellowish femora with dark minute rounded spots, yellowish tibia, and a broad yellowish stripe along the claval suture. Only two examined specimens have dark brown to black femora and only one of them has a narrow short yellowish stripe along the claval suture.

Despite some inconsistency in coloration, we suggest that the specimen described by Wagner represents a somewhat atypical nominal form of
O. vittipennis
, as only this species can be characterized by the large body and yellowish stripes on hemelytra. However, examination of this specimen is necessary to clear up the status of this subspecies.
